awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Middle and Late Cenozoic Surface Uplift and Climate along the Strike of the Rocky Mountains: Refining the Development of an Intracontinental Mountain Belt
awd_abstract_narration:
The Rocky Mountains of the western North America is the premier example of intracontinental mountain belts. Thick Cretaceous marine deposits provide unambiguous evidence that the region was near sea level at about 80 Ma ago. However, the history of subsequent vertical movements that formed present topography are less well constrained, yet crucial for understanding the tectonic processes and driving forces by which mountains form in continental interiors. This project aims to constrain the surface uplift of the Rocky Mountains and western Great Plains and associated climate changes during the last 35 million years. State-of-the-art isotopic methods will be used to estimate the paleotopography along transects in the northern and southern Rocky Mountains. The results will test the hypothesis that the timing and magnitude of uplift of the Rockies varied along its length, variations that can constrain the complex geodynamic processes the formed the Rockies during the this time period. The educational component of this CAREER award involve concerted efforts to engage students from underrepresented minorities in STEM and to provide teaching training to graduate students to better prepare them for academic careers. Specifically, the project will introduce professional activities and career outlooks of geoscientists to about 100 underrepresented minority high-school students in east Texas through a two-day long GEOCAMP, involve underrepresented high-school and undergraduate students in research, and train doctoral students to implement best practices in teaching for diverse learners as part of successful professional careers.

Recent geologic and geophysical observations of this classic intracontinental mountain belt demonstrate that the geodynamic drivers of Rocky Mountain uplift are complex and include: (1) late Cretaceous-early Eocene crustal thickening and shortening, or mantle dynamic processes related to low-angle subduction or the removal of an oceanic plateau; (2) middle Cenozoic detachment of oceanic slab; and/or (3) late Cenozoic mantle upwelling and thermal isostasy. The timing of occurrence and the role each mechanism played probably varied along the strike of the range. This project explores the idea that the timing and magnitude of the uplift of the Rockies varied along strike, and that these variations resulted from complex, but decipherable, geodynamic processes during the mid- to late Cenozoic. Specifically, the project will: (1) calibrate clumped isotope geothermometer of Quaternary fluvial carbonate cement in order to evaluate its application to paleoelevation and paleoclimate reconstructions; (2) improve the chronostratigraphy of the middle and upper Cenozoic strata in the Rockies and adjacent Great Plains as well as east Texas by determination depositional ages using detrital and tuff zircon U-Pb geochronology; and (3) document the paleotopographic and paleoclimatic evolution of the Rockies and the adjacent Great Plains along strike using carbonate clumped isotope and volcanic glass hydrogen isotope paleoaltimeters in order to understand the tectonic processes of the formation of the Rockies and associated climate changes during the middle and late Cenozoic.

por.por_cntn:
This project seeks to understand the surface uplift process of the Rocky Mountains (Rockies) and associated climate change in the western USA in the last ~45 million years (Myr). The study focused on three areas: south Texas as a sea-level reference site, a southern transect between southern Colorado and Kansas, and a northern transect between Montana and South Dakota. At the lowest level, the project improved the age constraints of the sedimentary rocks of the last ~45 Myr at these sites, by applying U-Pb isotope decay principles to volcanic-derived zircon grains mixed in sediment transport or deposition. This fundamental knowledge allowed us to put the reconstructions of surface uplift and climate change in time frame to further discuss the history of the Rockies. 

We then used stable isotope ratios of oxygen and hydrogen elements of ancient waters preserved in carbonate and hydrated volcanic glass minerals to reconstruct the elevations; and used U-Pb isotope ages of recycled zircon minerals to constrain the river drainage evolution. Because drainage patterns were dictated by topography change in the drainage basins, they also indirectly reflect uplift of the Rockies. We found that the timing and likely the mechanism of the surface uplift of Rockies are variable at different locations. The northern Rockies in northwestern Montana had a topographic relief greater than 2.5 km at ~45 Myr ago with the mountains higher than and the basins lower than today, and the relief became ~1.5 km because of filling up the basin with sediments as well as some degree of surface uplift by ~35 myr ago. The sustained high elevation of the mountains during the well-characterized extensional tectonics and sediment denudation is intriguing and we suggest it was likely caused by the isostatic and thermal effects of Farallon oceanic flat slab rollback and/or passage of a slab window and infusion of hot asthenosphere beneath the continent. However, in southwestern Montana, a stage of surface uplift occurred between 34-32 myr, after northwestern Montana, and we suggest the uplift was caused by removal of mantle lithosphere below the region. In southern Colorado, the Rockies seems to gain elevation in two steps, one before 34 Myr ago, driven likely by subduction and subsequent removal of the Farallon oceanic slab, and the other in the last 10 Myr, driven likely by local magmatic anomaly.

Climate changes in the Rockies in the last 40 Myr were both driven by global climate change and surface uplift of the Rockies which blocked moistures from the west. While near sea-level in south Texas, temperature and precipitation seem to remain stable, the climate in western Montana and southern Colorado became driver through time. A major cooling and drying event occurred in northwestern Montana at ~34 Myr ago, and the local terrestrial mollusks became less diversified after ~34 Myr ago. During this time, eolian deposition also became widespread in Wyoming.

The project partially supported the research and education of three PhD students and two postdocs, and involved six undergraduates in research. Two of the female undergraduate students published with the PI and continued graduate schools. We also outreached nearly 50 local high-school minority students and teachers. The outreach introduced them to local geologic features and lab equipment in the department, as well as the career outlook and education pathways for geoscientists. Participants all demonstrated interest to natural science after attending the outreach activities.
